MLRA_2015_4_592.JUDGMENT_NAME: DAMAI JAYA REALTY SDN BHD v. PENDAFTAR HAKMILIK TANAH, SELANGOR
MLRA_2015_4_592.JUDGE_NAME: Abdul Wahab Patail, Hamid Sultan Abu Backer, Umi Kalthum Abdul Majid JJCA

p.i: Civil Procedure: Judgment and orders - Validity of - Order for sale of estate land issued by High Court - Registrar of Land Titles refusing to register order for sale on grounds that approval of Estate Land Board not obtained - Order for sale not set aside - Whether Registrar had no option but to give effect to order for sale

Land Law: Sale of land - Order of court - Estate land - Whether such land prohibited from being charged as security without approval of Estate Land Board - Whether approval of Estate Land Board under s 214A National Land Code unnecessary in case of a sale under an order for sale by court

Land Law: Sale of land - Order of court - Sale of estate land by public auction - Registrar refusing to register order for sale or Form 16F on grounds that approval of Estate Land Board not obtained - Land charged notwithstanding express endorsement on title that land ought not be charged unless consent of State Authority received - Whether fact that land charged indicated consent of State Authority - Whether fact that land charged indicated State Authority knew if charge conditions were breached land would be sold to third party - Whether Registrar ought to have registered land

HEADNOTE.p: The appellant purchased a piece of land ("the property") at a public auction and received the requisite Form 16F Certificate under the National Land Code ("the Code"). The property was 40.3 hectares thereby bringing it within the purview of s 214A of the Code. The Registrar of Land Titles ("the Registrar") however refused to register the transfer of the property to the appellant on the basis that there was no approval by the Estate Land Board ("ELB"), whose approval was required by s 214A of the Code. The appellant appealed under s 418 of the Code to the High Court but the appeal was dismissed. The appellant thus appealed to the Court of Appeal.
Held, allowing the appeal with costs

(1) The clear terms of s 214A(10A)(b) of the Code that the execution of an agreement to convey or dispose of property without approval of the ELB are conclusive proof that the estate land is conveyed or disposed of in contravention of subsection (1), means that the approval must be obtained before such an agreement is executed. (para 8)

(2) An imbroglio occurs when a chargee seeks an order for sale. The chargee cannot make a joint application with a purchaser for the reason no purchaser is identified at that stage of the application for an order for sale. Likewise, the auction. The chargee cannot apply together with a purchaser for the reason the auction itself is to identify the purchaser. But a successful bid, thus identifying the purchaser, itself becomes a binding agreement, rendering the parties on the face of it to be in breach of s 214A of the Code. Such an interpretation, though on the face of it correct, overlooks the fact s 214A of the Code when incorporated into the Code was placed in Part Fourteen of the Land Code as to transfers, and to which s 267(1)(b) of the Code provides that the relevant provisions of the Part shall apply as if the chargor had transferred the land or leased to the purchaser in accordance with the provisions of that Part. (paras 10-11)

(3) Though transfer, conveyance or disposal of estate land are prohibited without prior approval of the Estate Land Board, nothing prohibits such land from being charged as security. Furthermore, s 267 of the code is a specific provision in respect of effect of an order for sale granted upon an application under s 256 of the code. Since s 214A is part of Part Fourteen of the Code, the words "as if the chargor had transferred the land or lease to the purchaser in accordance with the provisions of that Part" in s 267(1)(b), means that an approval of the ELB under s 214A of the Code is unnecessary in the case of a sale under an order for sale by the court. (para 12)
Per Hamid Sultan Abu Backer JCA:

(1) What was in issue before the High Court was whether the Registrar should have accepted the Certificate of sale pursuant to s 301 of the Code for the purpose of registration when s 214A(2) of the Code requires a certificate of approval from the ELB for registration. What was not considered by the court was the principle laid down by the Federal Court that all orders of court must be obeyed by the relevant parties, unless the order is set aside, a much entrenched principle in Malaysian jurisprudence. (para 15)

(2) In the instant case, the certificate of sale and/or order for sale had not been set-aside by the respondent and/or other relevant bodies. If the respondent and/or relevant authorities were aggrieved by the order of sale and/or certificate of sale, they had a duty and an obligation to make the necessary application to the court to set aside the order. However, what they could not do was refuse to comply with an order of court. Badiaddin Mohd Mahidin & Anor v. Arab Malaysian Finance Bhd (folld). (para 18)

(3) In the instant case, s 214A of the Code did not permit estate land to be transferred, conveyed or disposed off in any manner. Further, the title to one of the lots was endorsed with a restriction prohibiting the land from being transferred, charged or mortgaged without the consent of the State Authority. The fact that it had been charged and the charge registered on the face of the record showed that the State Authority must have consented and also knew the consequence that if the charge conditions were breached, the chargee had the right to sell the property to a third party. All interested parties relating to the State Authority knew of the consequence. If objection of the State Authority is to be taken in reliance of the endorsement or s 214A, it must be taken at the earliest opportunity. That was not done in the instant case. (paras 23-24)

(4) In the instant case, the State Authority fully knew or ought to have known from the date the consent to charge was allowed and/or registered the consequence of the breach by the chargor(s) if the repayment under the charge was not made. It would be abhorrent to the notion of justice and fair play for the State Authority and/or its agency to refuse registration. A responsible State Authority should help to facilitate registration, and where necessary provide the certificate of ELB as of right on the facts of the instant case. Nothing in the instant case was done in secret to defeat the law. Technical objections of such nature should not be allowed to prevail in view of ss 292, 267 of the Code as well as ss 297, 269 to 300, in particular s 299 of the Code. (para 27)

(5) In the instant case, the High Court judge had literally interpreted ss 214A and 301 of the Code. However, literal interpretation of s 214A as well as s 301, without balancing other provisions of the Code or Acts, case laws, Federal Constitution as well as the common sense approach relating to justice, equity and good conscience would result in a perverse judgment. (para 29)

(6) This was a fit and proper case to allow the appeal and direct the registration of the property within 60 working days from the date of the order with a direction that the respondent and/or the State Authority and/or agencies facilitate registration according to law. (para 30)

JUDGMENT.p: [1] The appellant/plaintiff Damai Jaya Realty Sdn Bhd appealed against the dismissal by the High Court of its appeal to that court pursuant to s 418 of the National Land Code ("the Land Code") against the refusal of the Registrar of Land Titles, Selangor ("the Registrar") to register a transfer of land ("the subject property") to the appellant/plaintiff pursuant to a Certificate of sale by court in Form 16F ("the Form 16F Certificate") under s 259 of the Land Code.

[2] The subject property was sold by auction pursuant to an application for an order for sale by a chargee under s 256 of the Land Code. Having (a) succeeded to purchase the property at the auction; and (b) paid the full amount of the purchase price, the appellant/plaintiff received the requisite Form 16F Certificate.

[3] The Registrar, however, refused to register the appellant/plaintiff for the reason that there was no approval by the Estate Land Board, whose approval was required by s 214A of the Land Code. The refusal by the Registrar stems from the fact that the land area of the subject property is 40.3 hectares, thereby bringing it within the purview of s 214A of the Land Code.

[4] The Form 16F Certificate certifies that the land or lease in question had been sold to the purchaser under the authority of the Land Code and the certificate shall, as provided by s 267 of the Land Code, be registrable by the purchaser as if it were an instrument of dealing, such that upon registration, the title or interest of the chargor shall pass to and vest in the purchaser, freed and discharged from all liability under the charge in question and any charge subsequent thereto.
[5] Section 267(1) of the Land Code provides that:
[6] Section 214A of the Land Code provides in respect of estate land as defined that:

[7] In Vellasamy Pennusamy & Ors v. Gurbachan Singh Bagawan Singh & Ors [2009] 5 MLRA 447; [2010] 5 MLJ 437; [2012] 2 CLJ 712; [2010] 4 AMR 381, it was held that there is no need to obtain approval first before entering into any form of agreement with the intended purchaser but there can be no transfer of the land, without approval of the Estate Land Board having first been obtained. In Tai Thong Flower Nursery Sdn Bhd v. Master Pyrodor Sdn Bhd [2014] 6 MLRA 713; [2014] 6 MLJ 341; [2014] 9 CLJ 74, it was held that the use of the words "desiring to transfer ..." and "to whom the land is to be transferred, ..." in s 214A(4) clearly meant that the obtaining of the approval must be done before the execution of the agreement by which the land would be conveyed or disposed of. Although it held that s 214A requires approval be obtained before the agreement is executed, the Court of Appeal remitted the matter to the High Court for the plaintiff to adduce evidence of such approvals.

[8] With respect, we hold the view that the clear terms of s 214A(10A)(b), that the execution of an agreement to convey or dispose of such property without approval of the Estate Land Board is conclusive proof that the estate land is conveyed or disposed of in contravention of subsection (1), means that the approval must be obtained before an agreement is executed.

[9] On the face of it, the Registrar acted correctly under s 214A of the Land Code. An application in Form 14D should have been made under s 214A, and an approval of such transfer, conveyance or disposal conveyed by the Secretary of the Board produced to the Registrar.

[10] None of the reported cases, however, concern a transfer under the Form 16F Certificate. An imbroglio begins when a chargee seeks an order for sale, for it cannot make a joint application with a purchaser for the reason no purchaser is identified at the stage of the application for an order for sale. Likewise the auction. The chargee cannot possibly apply together with a purchaser for the reason the auction itself is to identify the purchaser. But a successful bid, thus identifying the purchaser, itself becomes a binding agreement, rendering the parties on the face of it to be in breach of s 214A of the Land Code.

[11] Such an interpretation, though on the face of it is correct, overlooks the fact s 214A when incorporated into the Land Code was placed in Part Fourteen of the Land Code as to transfers, and it is specifically provided in s 267(1)(b) that:

[12] Though transfer, conveyance or disposal of estate land are prohibited without prior approval of the Estate Land Board, nothing prohibits such land from being charged as security. Furthermore, s 267 is a specific provision in respect of effect of an order for sale granted upon an application under s 256. Since s 214A is part of Part Fourteen of the Land Code, the words "as if the chargor had transferred the land or lease to the purchaser in accordance with the provisions of that Part" in s 267(1)(b), means that an approval of the Estate Land Board under s 214A of the Land Code is unnecessary in the case of a sale under an order for sale by the court. This interpretation avoids the imbroglio described in para 10 above as it no longer arises.

[13] We confine ourselves to the foregoing reasons to allow the appeal with costs at RM10,000.00, set aside the order of the High Court and direct the registration pursuant to the Form 16F Certificate within 60 days of this order. The additional reasons of His Lordship Hamid Sultan Abu Backer published in a separate judgment are, however, his own.

[14] The appellant appeals against the decision of learned High Court Judge who dismissed the appellant's appeal pursuant to s 418 of the National Land Code (NLC) against the decision of the Registrar of Land Titles, Selangor for failure to register an order for sale of the subject property notwithstanding a Certificate of Sale by court (Form 16F) had been issued and presented; the rejection purportedly on the grounds that the approval of the Estate Land Board (ELB) was not obtained came up for hearing on 20 October 2014 and we reserved judgment. In my view, one important issue fundamental to the rule of law and the Federal Constitution in relation to order of court and its compliance has arisen in the instant case and needs to be deliberated. [See Badiaddin Mohd Mahidin & Anor v. Arab Malaysian Finance Bhd [1998] 1 MLRA 183; [1998] 1 MLJ 393; [1998] 2 CLJ 75; [1998] 1 AMR 909]. This is my judgment allowing the appeal. My learned brother Abdul Wahab Patail JCA has written a separate judgment also allowing the appeal.

[15] The issue here involves Estate Land. Section 214A of the NLC does not promote the fragmentation of the Estate Land without the approval of the ELB. ELB comes within the compass of State Authority. The appellant has purchased Estate Land at public auction through the order for sale of a charged property. Under s 214A(11), Estate Land means any agricultural land held under one or more title which is more than 40 hectares. It is not in dispute that the land in question is about 40.3 hectares and it is an estate land. What was in issue before the High Court was whether the respondent should have accepted the Certificate of Sale pursuant to s 301 of the NLC for the purpose of registration when s 214A(2) requires a certificate of approval of ELB for registration. What was not considered by the court was the principle laid down by the Federal Court that all orders of Court must be obeyed by the relevant parties (unless the order is set aside), a principle which is much entrenched in our jurisprudence. (See Hadkinson v. Hadkinson [1952] 2 All ER 567). It is also well settled the motive for disobedience is irrelevant (R v. Poplar Borough Council (No 2) [1922] 1 KB 95). The failure to act and decide as enunciated by the Federal Court on the face of record is bad under the Federal Constitution, as it compromises the authority and jurisdiction of the court and paves way and also stands as a precedent for relevant parties to breach an order of court. The consequence of breach of order of court is a serious matter and amounts to contempt and the Federal Constitution preserves the power of the Superior Court to punish for contempt under art 126 to ensure orders of courts are complied by all, inclusive of all constitutional functionaries and its agencies, etc. (See Nik Noorhafizi Nik Ibrahim & Ors v. PP [2013] 6 MLRA 362; [2013] 6 MLJ 660 [2014] 2 CLJ 273; [2013] 5 AMR 854 and Nik Nazmi Nik Ahmad v. PP [2014] 4 MLRA 511; [2014] 4 MLJ 157; [2014] 4 CLJ 944).
[16] The Memorandum of Appeal (Tambahan) reads as follows:
[17] The conclusion of the learned judge reads as follows:

[18] In the instant case, the certificate of sale and/or order for sale has not been set-aside by the respondent and/or other relevant bodies. If the respondent and/or relevant authorities are aggrieved by the order of sale and/or certificate of sale, they have a duty and an obligation to make the necessary application to the court to set-aside the order. However, what they cannot do is refuse to comply with an order of court. In Badiaddin Mohd Mahidin & Anor v. Arab Malaysian Finance Bhd [1998] 1 MLRA 183; [1998] 1 MLJ 393; [1998] 2 CLJ 75; [1998] 1 AMR 909, the Federal Court observed:
[19] Section 214A of NLC states as follows:
[20] The jurisprudence relating to s 214A is set out in Janab's Key To Practical Conveyancing, Land Law and Islamic Banking, 2nd edn (2003) and reads as follows:

[21] It must be noted that case of Kumpulan Sua Betong Sdn Bhd v. Ezan Sdn Bhd & Anor [1993] 1 MLRA 302; [1993] 2 MLJ 289; [1993] 3 CLJ 337l; [1993] 2 AMR 1306 which says that transfer to one person is not caught by s 214A is no more applicable due to the amendment to Act 214A(1). In addition, s 214A and the forms to obtain consent from ELB relate only to the owner of the lease land and the intending purchaser of the Estate Land. [See s 214A(4)]. This section does not cater for foreclosure proceedings based on a charge, etc s 269 of the NLC gives protection to a purchaser of property in foreclosure proceedings and exempts the consent provision attached to the transfer, etc as set out in the s 269(2) of the NLC. The said s 269 of the NLC reads as follows:

[22] The Federal Court case of Pengarah Tanah Dan Galian, Wilayah Persekutuan v. Sri Lempah Enterprise Sdn Bhd [1978] 1 MLRA 132; [1979] 1 MLJ 135, will be a useful starting point to deal with the issues and necessary orders or directions which need to be given in the instant case. The facts of the Federal Court case read as follows:
And the Federal Court held:

[23] I have read the Appeal Record and the submissions of the parties in detail. I take the view that the judgment of the High Court must be set aside and direct the respondent to register the property as per the order of court and if necessary it is the responsibility of the State Authority to facilitate registration according to law. Our reasons inter alia are as follows:

[24] It will follow the property cannot even be charged without the consent of the State Authority and the fact that it had been charged and the charge registered on the face of record will show that the State Authority must have consented and also that the State Authority knew the consequence that if the charge conditions are breached the chargee has the right to sell the property to third party. In essence, all interested parties relating to State Authority knew of the consequence. If objection of the State Authority is to be taken in reliance of the endorsement or s 214A, it must have been taken at the earliest opportunity. That was not done in this case.

[25] Section 5 of the NLC defines the State Authority, which means the Ruler or Governor of the State, and it will follow the State Government of Selangor and all its agencies will fall within its compass of control, subject to the Federal Constitution, Federal Laws and State Laws. (See Majlis Perbandaran Subang Jaya v. Laguna De Bay Sdn Bhd [2015] 1 MLRA 662; [2015] 2 MLJ 509; [2015] 1 CLJ 357). Section 214(3) provides for the formation ELB which is controlled by the State Authority through its State Secretary, State Director and four members appointed by the State Authority from amongst the members of the public service. The State Authority under s 214A(9) has ample power to control the decision of the ELB.

[26] In the instant case, s 301 says 'when an instrument is fit for registration'. It also says that once the Certificate of Sale has been given consent by State Authority relating to restriction in interest to such land will not be applicable. Section 214A has been placed in Part Fourteen of the NLC and has nexus to s 292 when it relates to registration. Part Nine also fortifies the role of the State Authority in relation to subdivision, partition and amalgamation which has some nexus to the generic word fragmentation. The learned trial judge's proposition that the restriction of interest does not relate to s 214A without considering Part Nine (subdivision, partition of amalgamation) may not be totally correct taking into consideration ss 267 and 269 of NLC which guarantee the registration of the property once the Certificate of Sale is issued and also other provisions of Part Eighteen of NLC which imposes a duty on the respondent to facilitate registration. The definition of restriction in s 5 of the NLC reads as follows:

[27] State Authority under the definition means the Ruler, and it is trite that consent on land matter as in the instant case is not obtained from the Ruler but by the State Government and its agencies. In the instant case, the State Authority fully knew or ought to have known from the date the consent to charge was allowed and/or registered the consequence of the breach by the chargor(s) if the repayment under the charge is not made. It will be abhorrent to notion of justice and fair play for the State Authority and/or its agency to refuse registration. A responsible State Authority should help to facilitate registration, and where necessary provide the certificate of ELB as of right on the facts of the instant case. Nothing in the case was done in secret to defeat the law. Technical objection of such nature should not be allowed to prevail in view of ss 292, 267 of NLC as well as ss 297, 269 to 300 in particular s 299 of the NLC.

[28] Part Eighteen deals with registration of dealings as it has 26 sections. It attempts to give protection to the public from administrative abuse as in the instant case. It is the duty of the Registrar to facilitate registration. Sections 297 to 300 impose a duty on the Registrar to do so. This was not adhered to in the instant case.

[29] In the instant case the learned trial judge had made much effort to literally interpret s 214A as well as s 301. Literal interpretation of a statute is always subject to rule of law. The hallmark of interpretation and judgment writing in civil cases requires the court to consider justice, equity and good conscience in any decision making process which jurisprudence has been incorporated into our jurisprudence by case laws. (See Debnarayan Dutt v. Chunilal Ghose [1914] ILR 41 Cal 137). Literal interpretation of s 214A as well as s 301, without balancing other provisions of NLC or Acts, case laws, Federal Constitution, etc as well as the common sense approach relating to justice, equity and good conscience will result in a perverse judgment. For example, in the instant case, a purchaser who had paid about RM48.5 million and who had been guaranteed good title for registration under NLC has been prevented by the respondent from registering the property. Justice, equity and good conscience must be a starting and ending point to be considered in all decision making process and it is always subject to rule of law, and where the law is silent, the courts are obliged to deliver judgment according to justice, equity and good conscience, and at all times act within the framework of the rule of law and the Federal Constitution to preserve the integrity of the decision-making process. In National Union Of Bank Employees v. Director General Of Trade Unions & Anor [2014] 3 MELR 614; [2014] 6 MLRA 319; [2014] 6 AMR 143, the coram of Court of Appeal consisting of Abdul Wahab Patail, Linton Albert and Hamid Sultan Abu Backer in the interpretation of statute and the application of rule of law and Federal Constitution, had this to say:
[31] For reasons stated above, I will allow the appeal. The judgment of the High Court is set aside, with costs here and below.
[32] I hereby ordered so.
